_prev_prog_3.Description:
The primary objective of the RMP Program is proper oversight over the use of highly hazardous chemicals within Cape Cod Ice Facilities to prevent unwanted releases especially into locations which could expose employees, or the public to serious hazards. The framework to effectively manage and operate highly hazardous operations safely has been incorporated into the elements of the Risk Management program. 





The Elements that are included within the management system are provided below: 

1.    Management System 

2.    Process Safety Information 

3.    Process Hazard Analysis 

4.    Management System to Address Action Items 

5.    Process Hazard Analysis Review 

6.    Employee Participation 

7.     Operating Procedures 

8.     Emergency Preparedness 

9.     Training and Assessment 

10.     Contractor Management 

11.     Mechanical Integrity 

12.     Maintenance Systems 

13.     Pre-Startup Safety Review 

14.     Management of Change 

15.     Incident Investigation 

16.     Compliance Audits 



A Compliance Guidelines document is available for each of the elements, outlining the key requirements within that aspect of the RMP program. The Compliance Guidelines can be utilized as a tool within the company to assess potential implementation of certain elements. To support the Compliance Guidelines, specific written procedures detailing the method to meet the element requirements have been developed. In addition, the procedures will clearly define responsibilities for element compliance. Implementation of a specific element requires adherence to the corresponding written procedure. 

For any program to be successful, senior leadership is paramount. Leadership alone can make Process Safety a key business goal and provide the necessary resources to achieve both RMP and PSM objectives. Employees within every organization take their cues from administrators, managers and supervisors. If leadership consistently treats Process Safety as a priority, so will the rest of the work-group. At a minimum management commitment to Process Safety must include the following actions: 



1.    Visibly demonstrate leadership commitment to Process Safety 

2.    Clearly assign and communicate Process Safety responsibilities to all affected employees 

3.    Ensure leadership is aware of relevant Process Safety incidents 

4.    Implement system for ensuring Process Safety responsibilities are met 

5.    Integrate Process Safety into planning processes 

6.    Establish Process Safety goals and metrics for the covered process area(s) 



Cape Cod Ice has developed various mechanisms to document, implement, maintain and continually improve the Risk Management and Process Safety Management Systems to reduce process risks associated with critical operations. 

The primary objective of the RMP Program is proper oversight of the use of highly hazardous chemicals within The Cape Cod Ice Company to prevent unwanted releases especially into locations which could expose employees or the public to serious hazards. The RMP Program can also include critical operations identified by the organization through a risk assessment process. 

The framework to effectively manage and operate highly hazardous operations safely is incorporated into all Elements of the RMP program.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.1 STATIONARY SOURCE DESCRIPTION

The Cape Cod Ice East Providence facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia refrigeration to manufacture ice that is distributed throughout Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, and parts of New Hampshire.  The facility also stores cranberries during the winter months.

 

Cape Cod Ice's facility is located at 1 Noyes Avenue, East Providence, Rhode Island (East Providence facility). The refrigeration system is located throughout the warehouse building of the East Providence facility with the piping located on the roof.



1.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Cape Cod Ice relies on written procedures and training to minimize accidental releases.  Every employee must complete awareness training and operating and maintenance training for their particular duties and responsibilities prior to working on any assignment. If any processes change, employees are retrained in the new process before working on an assignment.



Contractors are required to be properly trained in the safety programs before doing any work at the facility.



All employees who operate, service, or maintain the ammonia refrigeration systems are trained to understand the safety and health hazards of the refrigerant and the refrigeration system at the facility. This knowledge is necessary for the protection of the individual, the other employees, and the community. 



Emergency Response Policy



In the event of an emergency, Cape Cod Ice personnel are expected to cooperate with fellow employees and other support personnel to assure successful resolution of any emergency. Cape Cod Ice employees are trained in emergency response for defensive measures only and rely on outside agencies to provide support in responding to an emergency. Outside support is required for both fire response and response to an ammonia release.



The E. Providence Fire Department and HAZMAT team shall notify the local emergency planning comm

ittee member (LEPC) in the event that an off-site response or an off-site evacuation is needed.



In the event an off-site response or an offsite evacuation is needed, the Emergency Response team shall determine the wind direction to help Fire Department and HAZMAT team determine which direction the plume is moving.



1.3 FACILTY LOCATION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Cape Cod Ice is located at 1 Noyes Avenue in East Providence, Rhode Island in a commercial area.



Cape Cod Ice stores one regulated substance on site above the threshold limitation, which is anhydrous ammonia. The threshold limit for anhydrous ammonia is 10,000 lbs. Currently, the facility has an estimated 20,550 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia.



1.4 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS

The EPA's RMP prevention program includes the requirements of the OSHA PSM standards. Cape Cod Ice currently has a Process Safety Management (PSM) program in place at the facility. The objective of the PSM program is to prevent accidental chemical releases and minimize their impact if they do occur. The focuses of the RMP and the PSM programs are to protect the employees and surrounding public. The EPA requires twelve (12) of the fourteen (14) elements of the PSM to be included in the RMP. The following twelve (12) elements are incorporated into the prevention programs for Cape Cod Ice:



o Process Safety Information

o Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

o Operating Procedures

o Training

o Mechanical Integrity

o Management of Change

o Pre-Startup Review

o Compliance Audits

o Incident Investigation

o Employee Participation

o Hot Work Permit

o Contractors



1.5 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENTAL HISTORY

There have been no reportable releases at the facility within the last five years.  



1.6 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

It is the policy of the Cape Cod Ice facility management to implement the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan by managing and operating the facility in accordance with applicable regulations and general good o

perating practices. The objective is to minimize the risk of a fire, or an accidental hazardous material release, including anhydrous ammonia.  Cape Cod Ice management has

developed the Emergency Action Plan to ensure a fast and efficient response in the event of an accidental hazardous material release, fire or other emergency situation.



Cape Cod Ice personnel are expected to cooperate with fellow employees and other support personnel as directed by the emergency response management to assure successful resolution of any emergency. Cape Cod Ice employees are trained in emergency response for defensive measures only and rely on outside agencies to provide support in responding to an emergency. Outside support is required for both fire response and response to an ammonia release. Therefore, Cape Cod Ice is a non-responding facility and has

developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure employees safety as required by the RMP regulation.



1.7 PLANS TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Cape Cod Ice has recently made some management changes in an attempt to better adhere to compliance and regulatory issues, and to improve the safety of employees and the surrounding community.
